verb.description: Be aware of (a person or object) through touching or being touched.
examples: she felt someone touch her shoulder
I felt a sense of excitement
we feel very strongly about freedom of expression

verb.description: Have a belief or impression, especially without an identifiable reason.
examples: she felt that the woman positively disliked her

noun.description: An act of touching something to examine it.
A sensation given by an object or material when touched.
examples: nylon cloth with a cotton feel
fans will undoubtedly get the feels when they see how things haven't changed
I cried a ton because I had too many feels

phrases: I most certainly do not feel my age but we are made to feel that we are well and truly past it.
He doesn't feel his age, 61, and loves performing and meeting the fans that still flock to these performances.
He misses her terribly, and for the first time, he is truly feeling his age.
feel free to say what you like
A manager told me that the lifeguards were confused, that it was not club policy, and that I should feel free to stay.
origin: Old English fēlan, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch voelen and German fühlen.
